whole_letter:
Dear Colleague,

I am referring Mr. John Doe, a 42-year-old male, to your expertise for further evaluation and management.

Patient Information:
Name: John Doe
Age: 42
Gender: Male

Mr. Doe was seen in our outpatient department complaining of moderate left upper quadrant abdominal pain. He has a known history of a liver hemangioma, diagnosed 1.5 years ago. A double helical CT scan revealed an 8.2 x 5.8 cm vascular lesion within segments II and III of the liver with peripheral nodular enhancement. Surgery was performed as per the described technique, with successful differentiation of the hemangioma's vascular pattern using ICG.

The reason for this referral is to request your specialized evaluation and management of Mr. Doe's liver hemangioma, given its size and associated symptoms. Your expertise would be greatly appreciated in determining the best course of action for his ongoing care.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to request your specialized evaluation and management of Mr. Doe's liver hemangioma, given its size and associated symptoms. Your expertise would be greatly appreciated in determining the best course of action for his ongoing care.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 44-year-old Caucasian female, to your specialist care. Ms. Doe visited our dental clinic seeking replacement for her missing teeth in the lower right mandible.

During her clinical examination, it was identified that she is missing the right mandibular 1st, 2nd, and 3rd molars. Severe bone resorption was evident, accompanied by inadequate amounts of soft tissue. Radiographic evaluation on CBCT scans confirmed severe vertical bone resorption. Based on these findings, we have scheduled pre-augmentation soft tissue expansion for Ms. Doe, followed by vertical bone augmentation and placement of dental implants.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please feel free to contact me if you need any further information.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Roe
referral_content: Ms. Doe visited our dental clinic seeking replacement for her missing teeth in the lower right mandible. During her clinical examination, it was identified that she is missing the right mandibular 1st, 2nd, and 3rd molars. Severe bone resorption was evident, accompanied by inadequate amounts of soft tissue. Radiographic evaluation on CBCT scans confirmed severe vertical bone resorption. Based on these findings, we have scheduled pre-augmentation soft tissue expansion for Ms. Doe, followed by vertical bone augmentation and placement of dental implants.

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 38-year-old woman, who recently presented to our hospital with a bulky lower lip. She was diagnosed with venous malformation (VM) of the lower lip based on preoperative T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Patient Details:
Name: Jane Doe
Age: 38
Gender: Female

The referral is made to your esteemed clinic to assess the patient for any further necessary treatment or follow-up. Although postoperative Doppler ultrasonography confirmed that the lesion was almost completely excised and the symptoms, contours of the lip, and radiologic findings all improved, further specialized evaluation is advisable to ensure comprehensive care and to prevent any potential recurrence.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dr. John Smith
Green Valley Hospital

Dear Specialist,

I am referring Mr. John Smith, a 43-year-old male with a medical history of asthma, who experienced a self-limited episode of hematochezia for 2 days. He denies any other gastrointestinal symptoms or relevant medication use. His physical examination and vital signs were within normal limits, and routine laboratory tests showed normal results.

A diagnostic colonoscopy identified a 0.6 cm sessile polyp in the cecum. A hot forceps polypectomy was performed, and routine immunostaining showed S100 positivity. The histologic examination revealed the polyp to be a ganglioneuroma.

Given the histological finding of a ganglioneuroma, further evaluation and management are warranted.

Thank you for your assistance in the continued care of this patient.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe
referral_content: Given the histological finding of a ganglioneuroma, further evaluation and management are warranted.

I am writing to refer a 19-year-old female patient, Jane Doe, who recently underwent eyelid surgery to address a 2 mm MRD1 on both eyes. The procedure involved excising excess skin and muscle through the incisional method, which also freed up adhesion-like septated tissue around the septum. Postoperative measurements at the 3-month mark showed significant improvement, with the MRD1 now at 5 mm on both eyes.

The reason for this referral is to seek your specialized evaluation and management of the patient's postoperative eyelid function, particularly to ensure that there are no underlying complications affecting her visual fields or eyelid mechanics.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,

Dr. John Harris
Eye Clinic, City Hospital
j.harris@cityhospital.com

Patient Information:
Name: Mrs. Jane Johnson
Age: 71
Gender: Female
Medical History: Pancreatoduodenectomy (Whipple)
Serum Creatinine: 0.56 mg/dL

The referral is made due to a recent computed tomography scan showing a 2.5 cm, circumscribed, enhancing mass in the right mid-kidney near the hilar. We seek your expert evaluation and management for further treatment and follow-up.

Thank you for your attention.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Roberts

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer my patient, a 5-year-old girl, who has been under our care since the age of 3 months. At that time, she presented with a pale face, fever, and cough. Her examinations revealed anemia, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and bronchitis. A widened interval outside the cerebrum was also noted on CT imaging. These findings were primarily attributed to suspected Evans syndrome and a viral infection.

Given that the patient is now 5 years old and displays no signs of physical or psychomotor retardation, we recommend further specialist evaluation to ensure ongoing stability and to address any potential underlying issues that may arise from her initial presentation. Your expertise in pediatric hematology and potential long-term management will be greatly beneficial.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. ExperiencedPhysician
referral_content: Given that the patient is now 5 years old and displays no signs of physical or psychomotor retardation, we recommend further specialist evaluation to ensure ongoing stability and to address any potential underlying issues that may arise from her initial presentation. Your expertise in pediatric hematology and potential long-term management will be greatly beneficial.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 56-year-old male who has been experiencing a persistent foreign body sensation in his left eye for the past 4 days. His best-corrected visual acuity is 6/6 OD and 6/9 OS. Opthalmic examination revealed a small epithelial defect on the cornea, while the rest of the external adnexa, bulbar conjunctiva, and palpebral conjunctiva appeared normal. Fluorescein staining confirmed the corneal epithelial defect.

Referral Reason:

Upon eversion of the eyelid for examination of the upper palpebral conjunctiva, pooling of fluorescein dye was noted around a tripod-shaped glassy foreign body. This indicates the presence of a foreign body that necessitates specialist intervention for removal and further management.

Your prompt attention to this matter would be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: Upon eversion of the eyelid for examination of the upper palpebral conjunctiva, pooling of fluorescein dye was noted around a tripod-shaped glassy foreign body. This indicates the presence of a foreign body that necessitates specialist intervention for removal and further management.

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 27-year-old woman with a confirmed R29X mutation, for further evaluation and management of her generalized dystonia. Her dystonia primarily affects her arms, trunk (mildly), and both feet. Additionally, she experiences marked oromandibular dystonia with significant tongue protrusion, impacting her speech since age 11. Initial symptoms began at the age of 7 and progressively worsened. Notably, her swallowing remains preserved despite the severity of her tongue involvement. There is no family history of similar conditions.

The primary reason for this referral is to explore advanced therapeutic options to manage her generalized and oromandibular dystonia, given the progressive nature of her symptoms and the impact on her quality of life.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely, 
Dr. John Smith

I hope this message finds you well.

Patient Information:
Name: John Doe
Age: 28
Gender: Male

John Doe presented to our facility with craniofacial injuries following a fall from his bike. He exhibited symptoms including bleeding from the left ear, soft tissue injury, pain in the left preauricular region, and limited TMJ movement despite normal occlusion. CBCT scans revealed a left temporoparietal fracture (TPF) and partial obliteration of the external auditory canal (EAC). Despite conservative treatment, the patient continued to experience occasional discomfort in the affected area.

The patient requires a referral to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation and management of his persistent symptoms and imaging findings. Specialist input is crucial to rule out any potential complications and to outline a comprehensive treatment plan.

Thank you in advance for your assistance.

Best regards,

Dr. Wilson

 Thank you,

 Dr. John Doe

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer a patient under your care. The patient is a 2-year-old male with a history of stage 4 anaplastic Wilms' tumor. Despite initial treatment with first-line chemotherapy, the metastatic lung disease was refractory, and the patient was switched to ICE chemotherapy. Following 4 cycles of ICE with PBSC support, a partial radiological response was observed. However, the patient experienced a second disease recurrence 3 months after undergoing high-dose melphalan with PBSC support.

The referral is for further evaluation and management of the recurrent disease. The progressive nature of the tumor despite aggressive therapy necessitates an expert opinion on potential salvage therapies or inclusion in clinical trials.

Thank you for your attention to this case. Please feel free to contact me for any additional information.

Best regards,
Dr. Alex Johnson
referral_content: The referral is for further evaluation and management of the recurrent disease. The progressive nature of the tumor despite aggressive therapy necessitates an expert opinion on potential salvage therapies or inclusion in clinical trials.

Dr. Brown

123 Main St, Springfield

Fundoscopic examination revealed a large central subinternal limiting membrane (ILM) hemorrhage in conjunction with a subhyaloid hemorrhage beneath the fovea and a breakthrough vitreous hemorrhage. Thank you for your attention in this matter.

Dr. John Clark
ABC Medical Center, Springfield

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 69-year-old female, who has been experiencing bilateral abdominal pain for the past 15 days.

Mrs. Jane Doe has undergone an ultrasound abdomen which showed anechoic fluid-filled avascular cystic spaces in the bilateral renal sinuses. A subsequent contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen revealed lobulated low-density peripelvic lesions in both kidneys splaying the collecting system. There was no contrast opacification of the lesions on delayed scans in the excretory phase, and no other abnormalities were observed in the rest of the abdomen. The patient has been managed conservatively thus far.

A specialist evaluation is required to further assess and manage the identified renal abnormalities.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Johnson

On neurologic examination, she exhibited complete flaccidity in the bilateral lower extremities with absent sensation from the umbilicus down. An MRI revealed a massive ventral spinal subdural hematoma extending from T12 to S1. 

Due to the findings on MRI, urgent surgical intervention was conducted to decompress and evacuate the hematoma. Considering the intricate nature of her condition and the potential for further complications, I recommend that she be evaluated by a specialist in spinal neurosurgery for ongoing management and follow-up care.

Please feel free to reach out for any additional information or clarifications.

Best Regards,

Dr. John Doe

Dr. Anderson,

Re: Jane Smith, DOB: 08/14/1999.

I'm referring Jane, a 24-year-old right-handed female diagnosed with recurrent left frontal glioblastoma (IDH mutant). During her recent evaluation, tb-fMRI showed no BOLD activation in the left anterior language area. Rs-fMRI was subsequently post-processed, and functional connectivity was identified in the left Broca's area using the left Wernicke's area as a seed.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer our patient, Ms. Jane Doe, a 54-year-old woman with a clinical and histopathological diagnosis consistent with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). She has no history of smoking and her tumor profile includes squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) confirmed by immunohistochemistry (IHC), which revealed positivity for p40 and p63 and negativity for TTF-1 and napsin-A. ALK protein overexpression was detected and confirmed via ALK rearrangement by IHC.

The patient initially received first-line chemotherapy with four cycles of gemcitabine and carboplatin, which failed to control tumor progression. Subsequently, she was treated with crizotinib as a second-line therapy and achieved stable disease (SD) but relapsed after six months.

Given the patient's progression on both first-line and second-line treatments, I am referring her for consideration of third-line therapy options, including potential enrollment in clinical trials targeting ALK-rearranged NSCLC.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. Should you require any further information, do not hesitate to contact me.

Best regards,
Dr. John Smith
referral_content: Given the patient's progression on both first-line and second-line treatments, I am referring her for consideration of third-line therapy options, including potential enrollment in clinical trials targeting ALK-rearranged NSCLC.

Diagnostic imaging included MRI using axial FIESTA sequences, which indicated superior mesenteric vein (SMV) swirling around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), consistent with midgut volvulus. This finding was corroborated by a plain CT scan. Coronal FIESTA and T2 fat-saturated images highlighted a prominent duodenal loop on the right side of the abdomen and jejunal loops on the right with ileal loops on the left, suggesting malrotation.

The patient requires specialized surgical assessment and possible intervention for midgut volvulus and malrotation.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe

Best Regards,
Dr. Alex Johnson

Immediate deep manual dissection was followed by intracameral air injection and the application of fibrin glue to seal the macroperforation. The graft was then sutured with 16 interrupted 10-0 nylon sutures. Ten days later, the patient experienced DM detachment, which was managed successfully with the injection of 20% sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas, resulting in the DM reattaching and remaining stable.

The patient now requires a specialist's attention to monitor the healing process and ensure there are no further complications related to the initial macroperforation or DM detachment. Your expertise in corneal graft management would be invaluable in ensuring the best possible outcome for the patient.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Dr. Doe

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer a pediatric patient, Emily Johnson, for further evaluation and management. Emily is a 6-year-old girl who has been diagnosed with moderate intellectual disability (ID) in association with multiple cardiac anomalies including atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) and atrial septal defect (ASD).

The primary reason for referral is the complexity of Emily’s cardiac defects coupled with specific genetic findings. Emily’s karyotype reveals an extrachromosomal marker and array-CGH indicates a 14 Mb duplication in the 18p11.32p11.21 region along with a 2925 kb duplication in 18p11.21-q11.2 regions. Given these genetic irregularities and the associated cardiac and intellectual manifestations, specialized genetic counseling and cardiologic assessment are warranted.

Emily presents minor facial dysmorphic features such as hypertelorism, low set ears, downslanted palpebral fissures, a flat midface, a small mouth, as well as bilateral incomplete transverse simian crease and clinodactyly. Both parents have normal karyotypes, further suggesting the need for specialized genetic intervention.

Thank you for your attention to this case. Please feel free to contact me for any additional information.

Sincerely,

Dr. Jane Doe

Emily’s karyotype reveals an extrachromosomal marker and array-CGH indicates a 14 Mb duplication in the 18p11.32p11.21 region along with a 2925 kb duplication in 18p11.21-q11.2 regions. Given these genetic irregularities and the associated cardiac and intellectual manifestations, specialized genetic counseling and cardiologic assessment are warranted.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. Edward Johnson, a 53-year-old Caucasian male, for further evaluation and management.

Mr. Johnson presents with nephrotic syndrome secondary to IgG-lambda amyloidosis. His current eGFR stands at 50 mL/min/1.73m². Initial tests revealed a calcidiol level of <20 nmol/L, with a parathyroid hormone (PTH) level of 12.6 pmol/L. Given his condition, he requires a cholecalciferol dose of 7143 U/day to reach a calcidiol level of >75 nmol/L.

I am writing to refer Mr. John Smith, a 74-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus, diabetic retinopathy, and atrial fibrillation, who was recently treated for MSSA bacteremia and an epidural abscess.

Mr. Smith was initially admitted for altered mental status and was found to have MSSA on blood and urine cultures. After initial treatment with vancomycin, his regimen was de-escalated to ceftriaxone. A transesophageal echocardiogram showed no vegetations, but an epidural abscess was later identified, along with septic brain emboli on MRI. He completed his hospital course and was discharged after 44 days, with an additional eight weeks of ceftriaxone therapy prescribed.

The reason for this referral is to ensure comprehensive follow-up and management of his recent infectious complications, specifically the monitoring and potential interventions required for the septic brain emboli and epidural abscess.

[Your Name], MD

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 65-year-old male patient, who presented to our clinic with a sudden diminution of vision in the right eye for one day. His best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) in the right eye was 10/200. Clinical examination using slit-lamp evaluation and measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP) was normal.

Fundus examination revealed a submacular hemorrhage (SMH) with a large pigmentary epithelial detachment (PED). Fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed blocked choroidal fluorescence, while indocyanine green angiography (ICG) indicated dye leakage consistent with a subfoveal choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM), confirmed by varying reflectivity on optical coherence tomography (OCT). His left eye was normal.

Given the findings, I am referring Mr. Doe for further evaluation and potential intervention by a retina specialist.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Wilson
referral_content: Given the findings, I am referring Mr. Doe for further evaluation and potential intervention by a retina specialist.

His physical examination revealed a plain angioma more prominent on the right side of his body, particularly the lower limb, along with verrucous nevi and angiokeratomas on the lateral surface of his foot.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 50-year-old female, for further evaluation and management.

Mrs. Doe has been experiencing progressively increasing painless swelling in her right arm for the past year. Clinically, the swelling is bony hard and non-mobile. Radiographic imaging of her right arm revealed an eccentric, lytic, and expansile lesion with a thin shell in the mid-diaphyseal region of the right humerus. MRI findings demonstrated a cortical-based expansile lesion with a heterogeneously hyperintense soft tissue component on fat-suppressed sequences, along with blood-fluid levels and extensive surrounding soft tissue and bone marrow edema.

Further evaluation by a specialist is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and discuss possible treatment options, including surgical intervention.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Sincerely,

Dr. John Roe
referral_content: Further evaluation by a specialist is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and discuss possible treatment options, including surgical intervention.

To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer Mr. Hiroshi Tanaka, a 43-year-old Japanese male, who presented with a sore throat for a duration of 3 months. Endoscopy revealed a tumor at the base of the tongue, and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Basal Cell Adenocarcinoma (BCAC). Initial staging via CT indicated T4aN0M0 (stage IVA), with a primary tumor diameter of 29 mm. Despite one cycle of chemotherapy at his previous hospital, including cisplatin, 5-FU, and docetaxel, there was no tumor shrinkage. He subsequently sought treatment at our institution, where Carbon-Ion Radiotherapy (C-ion RT) was administered.

The reason for this referral is to seek further specialized evaluation and potential surgical intervention for Mr. Tanaka's advanced BCAC, following the limited response to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Alex Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to seek further specialized evaluation and potential surgical intervention for Mr. Tanaka's advanced BCAC, following the limited response to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

The MS-39 epithelial map of the right eye showed increased epithelial thickness in the area of inferior steepening, compared to the normal epithelial thickness. However, there were no obvious stromal or posterior elevations in that area on the MS39 maps.

The basis for this referral is to further assess Mr. Doe's candidacy for refractive surgery, given the corneal topography findings and the increased epithelial thickness in his right eye.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,

Dr. Jane Wilson

Reason for referral:

Angiographic follow-up 6 months post-discharge indicated patency of the parent artery with no stenosis. Subsequent clinical follow-ups at 6 and 24 months showed no neurological deficits. I believe continuous monitoring by a specialist would be beneficial.

Thank you for your assistance.

Best regards,
Dr. John Doe

Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 77-year-old male with a medical history of atrial fibrillation and nonneovascular age-related macular degeneration (AMD). He presented approximately 4 hours after experiencing acute visual loss in his left eye. Examination indicated best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of count fingers. Fundus examination exhibited macular drusen as well as mild macular whitening and an early cherry red spot. SD-OCT revealed thickening and hyperreflectivity of the inner retinal layers, while FA at 26.58 seconds showed delayed retinal perfusion. The OCT-A retina slab, superficial slab, and deep slab demonstrated absent flow, consistent with the FA findings.

The reason for this referral is the acute visual loss in the patient's left eye and the associated retinal findings. Immediate specialized evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent further deterioration of his visual function.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Thompson
referral_content: The reason for this referral is the acute visual loss in the patient's left eye and the associated retinal findings. Immediate specialized evaluation and treatment are necessary to prevent further deterioration of his visual function.

Recent imaging, including axial T2-weighted MRI and coronal fat-saturated enhanced T1-weighted MRI, revealed heterogeneous hyperintense regions within the skeletal muscle. Dr. Experienced

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Emily Johnson, a 70-year-old female patient, to you for further evaluation and management.

Mrs. Johnson has a progressively increasing midline neck swelling which has been present for the past 10 years. Over the last 5 months, she has experienced hoarseness of voice, dysphagia, and generalized weakness. On physical examination, an oval, firm to hard swelling in the midline of the neck was noted, which moves with deglutition. Additionally, there is an enlarged left-sided cervical lymph node.

The referral is necessary to determine the underlying etiology of the neck mass, which could potentially indicate a malignancy or other serious condition requiring specialist assessment and intervention. Further diagnostic investigations including imaging and biopsy may be required.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dr. Michael Brown
Central Clinic

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring a 24-year-old female patient, Jane Doe, who has been diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). She presents with diffuse bone pains and proximal weakness for one and a half years, osmotic symptoms, and polyuria for 6 months. Her biochemical workup reveals hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and increased intact parathyroid hormone (iPTH) levels.

After examination, severe proximal weakness in the bilateral lower limbs and a 2x2 cm palpable nodule in the lower left lobe of the thyroid were noted. Skeletal imaging confirmed severe osteoporosis.

The referral is for further evaluation and management of the identified PHPT and associated severe osteoporosis.

Your expert evaluation and management are highly appreciated.

Best regards,
Dr. John Smith

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring a 4-year-old Caucasian male of Turkish nationality who presented with abdominal pain and biliary vomiting for three days. Physical examination revealed abdomen tenderness and rigidity. An X-ray showed air-fluid levels indicative of intestinal obstruction, and ultrasonic imaging (USG) demonstrated masses in the intestinal lumen. During surgery, necrosis of approximately 20 cm of the ileum was found, which was resected and two Ascaris masses evacuated. Primary end-to-end anastomosis was performed, and the patient was discharged on the 7th day postoperatively without complications.

The patient requires a follow-up assessment to ensure complete recovery and to identify any potential complications arising from the surgical resection and anastomosis, such as infection or intestinal adhesion. Your expertise in pediatric gastroenterology would be greatly beneficial for his continued care.

Thank you for your attention.

Best regards,
Dr. John Doe
referral_content: The patient requires a follow-up assessment to ensure complete recovery and to identify any potential complications arising from the surgical resection and anastomosis, such as infection or intestinal adhesion. Your expertise in pediatric gastroenterology would be greatly beneficial for his continued care.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to introduce an 8-year-old girl who suffered a grade 2 car-tire injury to her leg. The initial wound appeared clean, and progressive granulation was observed with regular dressing changes. On post-trauma day (PTD) 40, the granulation tissue was excised, and debridement was performed. An artificial dermis, accompanied by a split-thickness skin graft (STSG), was applied to cover the raw surface. During a 5-year follow-up period, no secondary deformity was noted, and the surgical outcome has been excellent.

The reason for this referral is to ensure the continued monitoring and management of the graft site for any potential long-term complications. Given the patient's excellent recovery thus far, I believe ongoing surveillance is critical to maintaining the surgical outcome's integrity.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

Dr. [Receiving Doctor's Name],

I am referring a 17-year-old male patient from Misiones, Argentina. Born to healthy, non-consanguineous parents, the patient has encountered several medical challenges since birth.

Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Age: 17
Gender: Male
Location: Misiones, Argentina

The reason for this referral is the patient has been diagnosed with Myhre-Well Syndrome (MWS). He exhibits symptoms including facial features consistent with MWS, congenital cardiomyopathy, generalized refractory epilepsy, bilateral hearing loss, hypoplasia of the corpus callosum, and severe neurodevelopmental delay with the absence of speech. Previous genetic testing, including karyotype and CGH array, returned normal results, but a genetic counselor strongly suspects MWS.

Thank you for your attention to this referral.

Sincerely,

Dr. [Your Name]

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 7-year-old male patient currently being treated with valproic acid for epilepsy. He was admitted to our Department of Paediatrics and Gastroenterology at the Medical University in Lublin due to symptoms of epigastric pain and vomiting.

On admission, the patient's laboratory findings revealed an elevated serum amylase activity of 982 U/L (reference value up to 118 U/L) and lipase activity of 1523 U/L (reference value up to 51 U/L). Abdominal ultrasound indicated a slightly swollen pancreas with decreased echogenicity, though serum valproate levels remained within therapeutic limits.

The referral is requested to evaluate and manage potential valproic acid-induced pancreatitis. Given the unusual presentation and the significant elevations in pancreatic enzymes, a specialist's insight is crucial for optimized patient care and management.

Thank you for your attention and prompt assistance.

Best regards,
Dr. Anna Kowalska
Department of Paediatrics and Gastroenterology, Medical University in Lublin
referral_content: The referral is requested to evaluate and manage potential valproic acid-induced pancreatitis. Given the unusual presentation and the significant elevations in pancreatic enzymes, a specialist's insight is crucial for optimized patient care and management.

To: Dr. Smith, Oncology Department

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 56-year-old female, who arrived at our institution for further diagnostic workup and possible treatment. The patient came in following the incidental finding of a hypoechoic 5 cm splenic nodule during an abdominal ultrasonography, which was part of her follow-up for a previous case of stomach Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST).

The reason for this referral is the high suspicion of a neoplastic lesion. The contrast-enhanced ultrasonography (CEUS), performed at another institution, described the lesion with centripetal early enhancement, an anechoic central component, and a progressive wash-out 44 seconds after injection, all of which suggest malignancy.

I kindly request your expertise in further evaluating and managing this potential neoplastic lesion.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Best regards,
Dr. Alan Brown
IRCCS Istituto Nazionale Tumori Milan

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 28-year-old female, who presented with persistent abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her physical examination was significant for right-upper-quadrant (RUQ) tenderness. Initial diagnostic imaging, including an abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography (CT), were negative. Additionally, a HIDA scan with cholecystokinin (CCK) was performed, which also returned negative results.

Despite comprehensive negative imaging, Ms. Doe continued to experience severe pain. As a result, a decision was made to perform a cholecystectomy for suspected clinical cholecystitis. She subsequently underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy with complete resolution of her symptoms.

At ten months post-operatively, Ms. Doe remains symptom-free and experienced significant improvement in her quality of life post-surgery.

Thank you for your attention to this case. Kindly extend further specialized care if needed.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith
referral_content: Despite comprehensive negative imaging, Ms. Doe continued to experience severe pain. As a result, a decision was made to perform a cholecystectomy for suspected clinical cholecystitis.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 36-year-old Caucasian male, who recently underwent surgical drainage of a neck abscess originating from teeth 47 and 48. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia with orotracheal intubation. Due to cervical tumefaction, nasotracheal intubation was not possible. Postoperatively, the patient presented with dysphonia, tongue deviation towards the right side, lingual motility disturbance, and swallowing difficulty. A barium swallow radiograph ruled out tracheoesophageal fistula, and a thorough neurological examination along with fibroscopy identified nerve paralysis.

The referral is primarily due to the postoperative nerve paralysis which has led to significant dysphonia, lingual motility issues, and difficulty in swallowing. The patient's current symptoms necessitate further specialized evaluation and potential intervention by a neurologist.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dr. Emily Brown
referral_content: The referral is primarily due to the postoperative nerve paralysis which has led to significant dysphonia, lingual motility issues, and difficulty in swallowing. The patient's current symptoms necessitate further specialized evaluation and potential intervention by a neurologist.

Dear Specialist,

I am referring Mrs. Janet Williams, a 72-year-old female patient, for further evaluation and management.

Patient Information:
Name: Janet Williams
Age: 72
Gender: Female

Mrs. Janet Williams presented with haematuria, dysuria, and pollakiuria. She was diagnosed with pyelonephritis. A thoracic and abdominal CT scan incidentally revealed thoracic and abdominal adenopathy. Subsequent laparoscopic excision of hepatic ganglia showed non-necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis.

The primary reasons for this referral are the incidental findings of thoracic and abdominal adenopathy and the histopathological discovery of non-necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis. Further specialist evaluation is warranted to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

Thank you for your assistance.

Best Regards,

Dr. Smith

Post-operative radiographs reveal conventional metaphyseal femoral, fibular, and tibial growth arrest lines. Additionally, there is an intra-epiphyseal distal femoral epiphyseal arrest silhouette that merits further specialist evaluation.

Given the persistent growth arrest lines noted in the radiographs, I recommend a thorough orthopedic and growth assessment. It is crucial to assess the potential impact on the patient's ongoing growth and plan appropriate interventions if necessary.

Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further details. 

Sincerely, 
Dr. Jane Doe

I am writing to refer a 27-year-old female patient who presented with severe persistent headache, persistent vomiting, decreased level of consciousness, and clonic seizures on the right side of the face and right upper limb with incontinence.

Upon examination, she was found to be confused with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (V2 M4 E2), displayed right facial asymmetry, hyporeflexia in both upper and lower limbs, bilateral extensor response in big toes in response to plantar stimulation (positive Babinski sign), and negative meningeal signs.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this referral.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe

123 Medical Lane
Yourtown, YS 12345

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mr. William Thompson, a 65-year-old male patient, recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic tract. Mr. Thompson has multiple metastases in the liver, peritoneum, and lungs. Following a single course of palliative chemotherapy with gemcitabine (1000 mg/m2), he developed a high fever and was hospitalized in poor general health.

The referral is for further evaluation and management of sepsis and multi-organ failure due to CMV infection. Despite initial stabilization attempts, Mr. Thompson's condition rapidly declined, leading to post-mortem confirmation of a Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection with a viral load of 3409 copies/ml detected via CMV-PCR. No other pathogens were identified in blood cultures.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this complex case.

Sincerely,

Dr. Sarah Johnson

Sincerely,
Dr. R. Singh

Dr. Emily Turner
First Care Clinic

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer a patient who requires your expert assessment and further management.

Patient Information: The patient is a thirty-three-year-old man diagnosed with hybrid leukemia, further specified as AML. He recently underwent induction chemotherapy, which included intravenously administered vincristine (2mg, weekly), adriamycin (45mg/M2 for 3 days), L-asparaginase (6000 IU/M2 for 12 days), and orally administered prednisolone (60 mg/M2 for four weeks). Referral Reason: The patient needs referral for further oncological assessment and management of acute gangrenous appendicitis complicated by leukemic infiltration. Given the complexity of his condition, specialist intervention is crucial to optimize his treatment plan and improve patient outcomes.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Emily Thompson

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Smith, a 60-year-old male patient, for further evaluation and management of his chronic migraines with aura. 

Mr. Smith has experienced episodic migraines for the last 5 years. These severe headaches, described as throbbing and rated 10/10 in intensity, typically start in the occiput and spread to the left supraorbital region. The episodes, which occur once per week and last about 10 hours, are accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. Rule For is_Papilledema : If the referral letter contains one of words in Synonyms, then is_Papilledema = true; If the letter contains words in PseudoSynonyms or doesn't contain words in Synonyms, then is_Papilledema = False.

Rule For referral_content : this content should be a whole paragraph which tells Patient need referral. If the referral_letter contains this content, you should include it. If the letter doesn't contain related information, then it should be null.
whole_letter:
To whom it may concern,

Patient Name: Jane Doe
Age: 61 years

Jane Doe presented weakly positive for anti-gp210 by immunoblotting and negative for ANA at the initial diagnosis with acute hepatitis E. Two months after discharge, she developed a new antibody displaying a rim-like ANA pattern with a titer of 1:80, accompanied by positive immunoblotting for anti-gp210. She maintained these antibody patterns one year post-discharge, with no evidence of PBC, as indicated by lack of symptoms, normal liver enzymes, normal abdomen ultrasound, and liver stiffness metrics.

We are referring Jane Doe for further immunological evaluation and monitoring. The persistence of rim-like ANA and anti-gp210 positivity warrants closer examination to rule out any underlying or evolving autoimmune pathology that might not be currently evident.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Dr. Alex Smith
referral_content: We are referring Jane Doe for further immunological evaluation and monitoring. The persistence of rim-like ANA and anti-gp210 positivity warrants closer examination to rule out any underlying or evolving autoimmune pathology that might not be currently evident.

To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 44-year-old Caucasoid male, for further evaluation and management. Mr. Doe is generally healthy except for experiencing very rare epileptic-like attacks.

Patient's Basic Information:
- Name: John Doe
- Age: 44
- Gender: Male
- Ethnicity: Caucasoid

Mr. Doe unfortunately suffered a sudden death while engaged in minor physical effort at work. Autopsy revealed his heart weighed 380.0 grams with dimensions measuring 14.7 cm by 12.0 cm. Notably, there was global dilatation and a congenitally malformed tricuspid valve resembling Ebstein’s Disease.

Given the significant cardiac abnormalities including global dilatation and a malformed tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle, further specialist input is essential to understand any underlying genetic or congenital basis and potential implications for family members.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith
referral_content: Given the significant cardiac abnormalities including global dilatation and a malformed tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle, further specialist input is essential to understand any underlying genetic or congenital basis and potential implications for family members.

To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Evelyn Johnson, an 89-year-old female, who has recently presented with cataracts and no prior ophthalmic history. During her preoperative evaluation, a delaminated anterior capsule was observed floating in the anterior chamber on slit-lamp biomicroscopy.

Patient Information: 
Name: Evelyn Johnson 
Age: 89 
Gender: Female 

The referral is for further ophthalmic evaluation due to the complexity observed during the cataract surgery. Histology of the anterior capsule revealed areas of focal splitting, which necessitates a comprehensive review by a specialist to determine the appropriate course of management and to monitor her recovery post-phacoemulsification.

Thank you for your attention.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Harris
referral_content: The referral is for further ophthalmic evaluation due to the complexity observed during the cataract surgery. Histology of the anterior capsule revealed areas of focal splitting, which necessitates a comprehensive review by a specialist to determine the appropriate course of management and to monitor her recovery post-phacoemulsification.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope this message finds you well.

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 32-year-old woman, for a comprehensive genetic consultation. Mrs. Doe carries an SH2D1A mutation that poses a significant risk of X-linked lymphoproliferative (XLP) syndrome in her offspring. The couple had previously lost two male children to severe EBV-associated hemophagocytic syndrome at the ages of 3 and 4, despite no family history of XLP.

The primary reason for this referral is to seek expertise in genetic counseling to prevent the inheritance of XLP in future pregnancies. They need guidance on possible interventions and options for family planning given the high risk of recurrence.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please feel free to contact me for any additional information.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith
referral_content: The primary reason for this referral is to seek expertise in genetic counseling to prevent the inheritance of XLP in future pregnancies. They need guidance on possible interventions and options for family planning given the high risk of recurrence.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 20-year-old male, who presented with notable clinical findings that warrant further neurological evaluation and management.

Name: John Doe
Age: 20 years old
Clinical History: Mr. Doe had a bike accident leading to a transient loss of consciousness and was initially managed conservatively for a thin right acute subdural hematoma. Despite an initial GCS of 15 and no deficits, he returned six weeks later with severe headache and bilateral sixth nerve palsy. Subsequent CT imaging revealed a right chronic subdural hematoma with mass effect. Burr hole drainage was performed, and complete recovery followed.

Referral Reason: Mr. Doe presents papilledema on fundus examination, suggesting increased intracranial pressure. Further evaluation by a specialist is necessary to rule out any underlying conditions and to manage the ongoing risk of complications due to his history of subdural hematomas.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this referral.

Best regards,

Dr. Smith
referral_content: Mr. Doe presents papilledema on fundus examination, suggesting increased intracranial pressure. Further evaluation by a specialist is necessary to rule out any underlying conditions and to manage the ongoing risk of complications due to his history of subdural hematomas.

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 75-year-old female with a complex medical history including recurrent hospitalizations for atrial fibrillation, heart failure, and sepsis.

The referral reason: Mrs. Doe recently presented to our emergency room with circulatory collapse. Upon investigation, it was discovered she had hyponatremia and subnormal thyroid function secondary to long-term amiodarone therapy. She has never been diagnosed with hypothyroidism. Despite conventional care and interventions including thyroid hormone administration and mechanical ventilation, her condition deteriorated.

She requires specialized endocrinology evaluation and further management to prevent potential future complications.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. John Adams

Dear Dr. [Specialist's Name],

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 38-year-old female, weighing 65 kg, who has been diagnosed with two large atrial septal defects (ASDs). 

The referral is being made because despite our attempts to close the central defect via transcatheter approach using both guide wires and a sizing balloon, we encountered difficulties suggesting a possible third defect. Consequently, we referred her for surgical closure. During the operation, the surgeon confirmed that there were only two defects. Post-operative follow-up was successful with no residual shunt observed.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. John Smith

Post-operative follow-up was successful with no residual shunt observed.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 66-year-old male with a complex medical history including gastric lymphoma treated with chemotherapy, who subsequently developed pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). He has been on TB medications, experiencing significant symptoms including vomiting and an 80-pound weight loss.

Mr. Doe underwent an endoscopy that revealed a pyloric ulcer causing outlet obstruction and proximal gastric ulcers. Efforts to place a jejunal extension to a percutaneous gastrostomy tube by interventional radiology were unsuccessful due to severe pyloric narrowing. As he is a poor surgical candidate, he remains on total parenteral nutrition and is in respiratory isolation.

The primary reason for this referral is the unsuccessful placement of the jejunal extension due to severe pyloric narrowing, which needs further expert evaluation and management.

Please feel free to contact me for further information.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith
referral_content: The primary reason for this referral is the unsuccessful placement of the jejunal extension due to severe pyloric narrowing, which needs further expert evaluation and management.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 67-year-old woman with a history of osteoarthritis (KL grading III) in her right hip. She is 153 cm tall and weighs 54 kg. She initially presented with pain in her right hip joint, which has since shown periods of remission and deterioration. Currently, her pain has significantly decreased to P0. However, recent radiographs still indicate OA at KL grading III, and an MRI showed no signal changes in the right hip joint.

whole_letter:
Dear Specialist,

I am referring a 53-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with cavernous angioma (CG) since 2003, noted for its slow progression. He presented recently with diplopia and headache persisting for a couple of weeks. MRI results reveal a 2.2 x 1.4 cm lesion in the transversal plane above the apex of the right os petrosum, characterized by a high-intensity signal on both T1 and T2-weighted imaging and a low-intensity rim on T2-weighted imaging. 

The reason for this referral is to evaluate and manage the identified lesion further, considering the progression of symptoms and the MRI findings. 

Thank you for your evaluation.

Best regards,
Dr. John Doe
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to evaluate and manage the identified lesion further, considering the progression of symptoms and the MRI findings.

Dr. John Doe, First Affiliated Hospital of China Medical University

Dear Dr. Doe,

I am referring Mr. Robert Smith, a 48-year-old male, who was evaluated in August 2011 for a non-tender, soft mass in the left parotid region. The ultrasound revealed a nonhomogenous hypoechogenic mass with anechogenic areas measuring 21x12 mm. After undergoing parotidectomy, he has shown no signs of tumor recurrence or metastasis during the 16 months follow-up.

The reason for this referral is the need for specialized follow-up to monitor any potential recurrence of the parotid mass. Given the initial findings and surgical intervention, continued vigilance is essential to promptly address any emerging concerns.

Please find attached the relevant medical records for your review. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Smith

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Ms. Sarah Johnson, a 47-year-old multiparous female. Ms. Johnson recently underwent diagnostic mammography and breast ultrasound, which revealed a high-density irregular lesion with microcalcifications in the retroareolar and medial aspect of her breast. This lesion was categorized as BIRADS grade 5.

Patient Information:
Name: Ms. Sarah Johnson
Age: 47 years
Gender: Female
Medical History: Multiparous, high-density irregular lesion in breast

The referral is necessary due to the confirmed diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC). The core biopsy indicated malignant features, including marked hypoechogenicity and microlobulations. The urgency of the referral is underscored by the presence of microcalcifications and dilated anechoic ducts in the retroareolar region, although no satellite lesions or axillary lymph nodes were detected.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Emily Davis
referral_content: The referral is necessary due to the confirmed diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC). The core biopsy indicated malignant features, including marked hypoechogenicity and microlobulations. The urgency of the referral is underscored by the presence of microcalcifications and dilated anechoic ducts in the retroareolar region, although no satellite lesions or axillary lymph nodes were detected.

To: Spine Specialist,

Dear Dr. Smith,

Patient Information:

Name: Jane Doe
Age: 31
Gender: Female

We are referring Jane Doe, who has been under our care for a mass in the sacrum that was initially identified via Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Following Subtotal Resection (STR), pathology revealed a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT). A subsequent Computed Tomography (CT) scan indicated remnant tumor tissue on the ventral side of the S2 spinal canal.

Referral Reason:

The patient requires further evaluation and potential follow-up treatment for the remnant tumor tissue located in the ventral side of the S2 spinal canal. Despite a Gross Total Resection (GTR) four months ago and no recurrence after ninety-four months, continuous specialized assessment is crucial for ensuring long-term health and managing any potential complications.

Thank you for your assistance in continuing her care.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Miller

Sunrise Hospital
referral_content: The patient requires further evaluation and potential follow-up treatment for the remnant tumor tissue located in the ventral side of the S2 spinal canal. Despite a Gross Total Resection (GTR) four months ago and no recurrence after ninety-four months, continuous specialized assessment is crucial for ensuring long-term health and managing any potential complications.

I am writing to refer a 77-year-old male patient to your care. He has a history of nonexudative AMD and presented at our Retina Clinic with significantly reduced vision in his right eye. His visual acuity is currently counting fingers in this eye. Further examination revealed subretinal hemorrhage, paracentral geographic atrophy, and soft drusen.

The referral is necessary due to the findings indicating possible occult CNV adjacent to the blocked fluorescence from subretinal hemorrhage, as evidenced by FA and composite OCT showing a red vascular signal extending from the choroid into a solid PED, consistent with vascularization. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. 

Sincerely,

Dr. Jane Doe

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer my patient, Mrs. Jane Doe, a 55-year-old female with a history of lung adenocarcinoma characterized by KIF5B-RET rearrangement and brain metastasis.

Mrs. Doe was initially treated with second-line cabozantinib, but after four months, she exhibited intrathoracic progression. A rebiopsy confirmed lung adenocarcinoma with KIF5B-RET fusion and a high PD-L1 expression (TPS = 50%). She was subsequently started on pembrolizumab, achieving a confirmed partial response both intrathoracic and intracranial as per iRECIST criteria.

The reason for referral is the observed progression despite initial therapy and the need for evaluation and consideration of further treatment options. Given the high PD-L1 expression and her partial response to pembrolizumab, specialized insight into potential next steps would be beneficial.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. John Green
referral_content: The reason for referral is the observed progression despite initial therapy and the need for evaluation and consideration of further treatment options. Given the high PD-L1 expression and her partial response to pembrolizumab, specialized insight into potential next steps would be beneficial.

I am writing to refer Ms. Jane Doe, a 29-year-old female patient under my care, who has been experiencing significant complications following the initiation of SILSI therapy.

Patient Information:
Name: Jane Doe
Age: 29
Condition: Iatrogenic Subglottic Stenosis (SGS), Diagnosed with Cushing's Syndrome
Initial SILSI Start: 4.8 months ago

Ms. Doe presented to her primary care provider 4.6 months after initiating SILSI with significant side effects including a 53-lb weight gain, moon facies, and poor glycemic control. Due to her status as a high-risk surgical patient, it was decided to continue SILSIs with a reduced frequency.

Referral Reason: Ms. Doe requires specialized endocrine evaluation and management of her Cushing's Syndrome, given her complex clinical presentation and the challenges posed by her current treatment regimen. A specialized assessment and potential alteration in her treatment plan are necessary to optimize her overall health outcomes.

Please contact our office for any further information needed.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith

A specialized assessment and potential alteration in her treatment plan are necessary to optimize her overall health outcomes.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, 
Dr. Jane Roe

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am referring Mrs. Jane Doe, a 74-year-old female, who has presented with a 3-week history of stereotyped episodes of tingling and numbness. These symptoms start in her right arm and spread to contiguous body parts, including her face, arm, and leg. She has experienced 5-7 such events per day for the last 3 years. Her clinical examination and EEG have been normal.

MRI of the brain showed subcortical hemosiderin deposits on gradient echo sequences (GRE), which is typical of Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA). The patient's symptoms have responded well to Topiramate 25 mg taken twice daily, which has successfully terminated the attacks.

The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage her diagnosed Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy and to consider alternate or adjunctive therapeutic strategies.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Alex Brown
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage her diagnosed Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy and to consider alternate or adjunctive therapeutic strategies.

Dear Specialist,

I am referring a 15-year-old boy who has been diagnosed with Noonan syndrome and focal epilepsy. The patient presents a unique case as he was also diagnosed with a left-sided brain tumor located near the primary motor cortex at the age of 12. Histology after tumor resection confirmed the presence of a dysembryoplastic neuroepithelial tumor (DNET) WHO I.

The reason for referral is to evaluate and manage his medication-resistant focal epilepsy, which has persisted despite comprehensive treatment. This patient requires specialized care to optimize his epilepsy management.

The patient attends normal school and shows no motor or cognitive deficits, which is a testament to the success of previous interventions. However, the persistent epilepsy remains a significant concern that warrants your specialized expertise.

Thank you for your attention and assistance in this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith.
referral_content: The reason for referral is to evaluate and manage his medication-resistant focal epilepsy, which has persisted despite comprehensive treatment. This patient requires specialized care to optimize his epilepsy management.

Dr. John Doe, Cardiothoracic Surgeon
123 Health Services Ave.
City, State, ZIP

Dear Dr. Doe,

I am writing to refer a 7-year-old male patient with a documented history of Kawasaki disease treated conservatively at the age of 1 year, who is now presenting with significant cardiovascular issues.

The patient currently exhibits shortness of breath classified as NYHA class 3. Recent echocardiography findings are suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy with an LVEF of 30%. The angiogram shows a normal RCA but a cut-off in the mid part of the LMCA with collateral filling from the right coronary. Cardiac stress testing further indicated the presence of provocable ischemia.

The reason for this referral is to evaluate the patient for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). Given the complexity of his condition and the confirmed ischemia, your expertise in cardiothoracic surgery is vital for determining the appropriate surgical interventions.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. Please let us know if you require any additional information.

Kind regards,

Dr. Jane Smith
Pediatric Cardiologist
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to evaluate the patient for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). Given the complexity of his condition and the confirmed ischemia, your expertise in cardiothoracic surgery is vital for determining the appropriate surgical interventions.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Smith, a 54-year-old male patient, for further evaluation.

Mr. Smith has presented with a painless, lobulated soft tissue mass located in the labial mucosa, which has been present for the past 10 years. The mass measures 2x3 cm, has smooth margins, and is not fixed to underlying deeper structures. The oral mucosa overlying the mass appears normal. His full blood count, serum urea and electrolytes, and urine analysis are all within normal limits. There is no history of fever, weight loss, or any other otolaryngeal problems.

The reason for this referral is to obtain a specialist opinion and possible biopsy to determine the etiology of this long-standing mass and to explore appropriate management options, which may include surgical excision.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jane Doe
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to obtain a specialist opinion and possible biopsy to determine the etiology of this long-standing mass and to explore appropriate management options, which may include surgical excision.

Thank you,

whole_letter:
Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 21-year-old male patient who presents with episodic stiffness of his extremities and trunk when he attempts to start sudden exercise. The symptoms began at age 12, and there is no family history of similar issues. The patient has denied episodic muscle weakness or cold sensitivity. Physical examination revealed normal muscle strength with no hypertrophy. Laboratory tests were largely unremarkable, except for mildly elevated serum CK levels (463 IU). Needle EMG showed myotonic discharges. Treatment with Mexiletine has provided moderate symptom relief.

The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage the persistent episodic stiffness, given the patient's partial response to medication. Additional specialist insights and possibly advanced diagnostics may be beneficial for more definitive management.

Thank you for your attention.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to further evaluate and manage the persistent episodic stiffness, given the patient's partial response to medication. Additional specialist insights and possibly advanced diagnostics may be beneficial for more definitive management.

To Whom It May Concern,

The patient, an 8-year-old boy, was diagnosed with congenital pseudarthrosis forearm type II affecting both the radius and ulna. Following surgical procedures including resection and Ilizarov external fixation/traction, a secondary free fibula osteoseptocutaneous flap was harvested and transferred to cover the tissue defects.

The reason for referral is to provide specialized follow-up care to assess the integration and healing of the fibula flap, as well as to ensure continued functional recovery of the affected forearm. The expertise of a specialized orthopedic surgeon is required due to the complexity and rarity of the condition.

Please feel free to contact me if you require any further details.

Sincerely,
Dr. Smith
Contact: 123-456-7890
referral_content: The reason for referral is to provide specialized follow-up care to assess the integration and healing of the fibula flap, as well as to ensure continued functional recovery of the affected forearm. The expertise of a specialized orthopedic surgeon is required due to the complexity and rarity of the condition.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mr. John Anderson, a 69-year-old male with a significant medical history, primarily marked by heavy alcohol use and recurrent hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). He underwent transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) twice at another hospital seven years ago and had a left hepatectomy one year before our surgery. Post-hepatectomy, a recurrent HCC in segment 8 was treated with radiofrequency ablation. Recently, a tumor thrombus was detected in the inferior vena cava (IVC), right atrium (RA), and phrenic vein.

The referral is for further evaluation and management of the tumor thrombus, given its close proximity to the stump of the remnant liver and left hepatic vein. This condition requires specialized intervention to prevent further complications.

Thank you for your attention and expertise in this matter.

Sincerely,
Dr. Emily Watson
referral_content: The referral is for further evaluation and management of the tumor thrombus, given its close proximity to the stump of the remnant liver and left hepatic vein. This condition requires specialized intervention to prevent further complications.

Dear Dr. Smith,

I hope this message finds you well. 

Patient: Jane Doe
Age: 25
Gender: Female
Race: White

Jane Doe, a 25-year-old white female, initially presented with breast hypotrophy and underwent breast augmentation with 400 ml round smooth, moderate profile silicone implants inserted through an inferior periareolar incision. Six months post-procedure, she consulted again due to bottoming out of both implants. A revision surgery was performed, involving an infra-mammary incision with capsulectomy and capsuloplasty, to redefine the new inframammary fold without changing the implants.

Referral Reason: The patient now requires further consultation due to persistent issues post-revision surgery, especially focusing on the long-term stability and positioning of the implants, as well as any additional corrective measures that may be necessary.

Thank you for your attention and expertise in this matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Johnson
referral_content: The patient now requires further consultation due to persistent issues post-revision surgery, especially focusing on the long-term stability and positioning of the implants, as well as any additional corrective measures that may be necessary.

Dr. John Smith,
Cardiology Department,
General Hospital

Dear Dr. Smith,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 65-year-old female with a history of dyslipidemia and coronary heart disease. She previously lost vision in her right eye due to Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) and has been experiencing left scalp tenderness despite treatment with low-dosage glucocorticoids.

The reason for this referral is the confirmation of a GCA relapse. TA CDUS revealed bilateral halo signs and an intima-media thickness (IMT) of 0.7 cm. Although after six months of treatment with tocilizumab (TCZ), inflammatory markers have normalized and the left TA CDUS was negative, the halo sign remains in the contralateral TA.

Considering her complex medical history and the persistence of the halo sign, I believe that further specialized cardiological evaluation is warranted.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Dr. Emily Clark

Although after six months of treatment with tocilizumab (TCZ), inflammatory markers have normalized and the left TA CDUS was negative, the halo sign remains in the contralateral TA.

Dr. Lisa Turner,

I am writing to refer Ms. Emily Johnson, a 48-year-old woman, for further oncological evaluation. Ms. Johnson presented with acute right lower abdominal pain and was diagnosed with acute appendicitis, for which an appendectomy was performed.

Patient: Emily Johnson
Age: 48
Diagnosis: Acute Appendicitis with Malignant Papillary Epithelial Proliferation
Histology: Small, fibrotic appendix with papillary epithelial proliferation, cellular atypia, positive p53 protein, and Ki-67 labeling at 90%

The referral reason is to evaluate the malignant features observed in the appendiceal mucosa. Specifically, while there are no invasive features and no pseudomyxoma peritonei was recognized, the cellular atypia and high Ki-67 labeling index suggest a need for further oncological assessment to rule out any potential malignancy or need for additional treatment.

Ms. Johnson is currently healthy without evidence of metastasis or recurrence 37 months post-operation.

Sincerely,
Dr. Michael Smith
referral_content: The referral reason is to evaluate the malignant features observed in the appendiceal mucosa. Specifically, while there are no invasive features and no pseudomyxoma peritonei was recognized, the cellular atypia and high Ki-67 labeling index suggest a need for further oncological assessment to rule out any potential malignancy or need for additional treatment.

Dr. Sarah Thompson
Pediatric Neurology Clinic
123 Health Blvd
Cityville

Dear Dr. Thompson,

I am writing to refer Emily Clark, a 12-year-old patient, for further evaluation and management.

Patient Information:
Name: Emily Clark
Age: 12 years old
Current Diagnosis: Dravet syndrome

Emily was diagnosed with Dravet syndrome at five and a half months, after initially having normal psychomotor development. She has since developed complex partial seizures that have secondary generalization, as well as tonic-clonic and myoclonic seizures that are resistant to pharmacological treatment. Additionally, she has experienced developmental delay and ataxia. Her EEG showed repeated right-sided and occasional diffuse background activity slowing to 2-4 Hz with isolated spike-wave discharges, predominantly in the frontal and central areas. Genetic analysis identified the p.E78* mutation, though brain MRI revealed no significant signal changes.

Emily requires further specialized care to manage her refractory seizures and developmental issues, which necessitates your expertise in pediatric neurology.

Thank you for your assessment and management of this patient.

Sincerely,
Dr. John Smith
General Pediatrician
Cityville Clinic
referral_content: Emily requires further specialized care to manage her refractory seizures and developmental issues, which necessitates your expertise in pediatric neurology.

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 41-year-old male with a known case of left atrial AVM. He recently presented in an unconscious state with a Glasgow coma score of 4 and a Graeb score of 9, secondary to massive intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH). The motor response was decerebrate, and pupils were pinpoint bilaterally.

Mr. Doe has been operated on as an emergency case utilizing 30-degree neuroendoscopy, with the administration of one ampoule of recombinant factor VIIa prior to surgery. After one month of rehabilitation, he achieved a good recovery.

Mr. Doe is now being referred for AVM radiosurgery. Given the nature of his recent medical history and the need for specialized care, your expertise will be invaluable in his continued management.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Best regards,

Dr. Emily White
referral_content: Mr. Doe is now being referred for AVM radiosurgery. Given the nature of his recent medical history and the need for specialized care, your expertise will be invaluable in his continued management.

I am writing to refer John Doe, a 17-year-old male with a history of ESRD secondary to primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH 1). John has been on haemodialysis for the past 2 years and was enlisted in the cadaver organ transplantation programme. He successfully received a kidney from an 18-year-old deceased donor two years ago.

The referral reason for John is for a follow-up evaluation of his kidney transplant. Although he has been doing well post-transplant with improved ejection fraction and serum oxalate levels, a specialized transplant nephrologist's assessment would ensure optimal long-term management and detect any potential complications early.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. Please feel free to contact me if you need any additional information regarding John's medical history.

Best regards,
Dr. Sarah Smith

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer Mrs. Jane Doe, a 42-year-old female patient. She has a notable medical history including a BRCA1 mutation and recently developed Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS), detected only 4 months after her genetic testing. Over the past seven years, Mrs. Doe has been undergoing annual check-ups due to her significant family history of breast cancer.

Patient Information:
Name: Jane Doe
Age: 42
Family History: Sisters diagnosed at 38 and 45 years; paternal grandmother diagnosed at 70 years.
Recent Medical History: Developed DCIS, detected by MMG examination.
Treatment: Underwent total mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy, pathologic stage 0.

The reason for referral is to ensure comprehensive post-operative surveillance and management of the patient’s condition, given her genetic predisposition and recent diagnosis of DCIS. She requires specialized follow-up care to monitor for any potential recurrence or new developments.

Thank you for your attention to this case.

Best regards,
Dr. Smith

To: Oncology Department,

Dear Colleagues,

I am writing to refer a 55-year-old female patient presenting with complex dermatological findings. The patient has an infiltrated, pseudo-vesicular plaque with well defined borders (2 x 1.5 cm) on the proximal region of her left arm. Numerous small erythematous papules are present on the periphery of the lesion. Dermoscopy under polarized light revealed chrysalis, linear-irregular vessels, globules, and milky-red areas. Histopathology indicates nodular Acral Melanocytic Melanoma (AMM) with a Breslow depth of 11.0 mm and Clark level V, along with epidermotropic melanoma metastasis. Additionally, there is a basal cell carcinoma (BCC) located on the frontal region.

The reason for this referral is the need for specialized oncological assessment and treatment planning for advanced melanoma and concurrent BCC. The severity and complexity of the patient's conditions necessitate advanced medical intervention.

Thank you for your assistance.

Kind regards,

[Your Name] [Your Contact Information]
referral_content: The reason for this referral is the need for specialized oncological assessment and treatment planning for advanced melanoma and concurrent BCC. The severity and complexity of the patient's conditions necessitate advanced medical intervention.

Dr. John Anderson

Dear Cardiology Department,

I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to refer Mr. Wei Zhang, a 26-year-old Chinese male, who presented with dyspnea, fatigue, arrhythmias, fever, and cough. He was admitted to our hospital on June 6, 2019, and diagnosed with infective endocarditis, heart failure, and ventricular septal defect, manifesting with inflammatory response syndrome. His medical history includes uncontrolled hypotension and rheumatic heart disease. Initial lab testing showed no abnormalities, though the electrocardiogram revealed a high echo of the tricuspid valve suggesting a neoplasm.

The referral is due to the complexity and severity of his conditions, particularly the diagnosis of infective endocarditis coupled with heart failure and a potential neoplasm on the tricuspid valve. Specialized cardiac evaluation and management are urgently needed to devise an appropriate treatment plan.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, 

Dr. Mei Ling
referral_content: The referral is due to the complexity and severity of his conditions, particularly the diagnosis of infective endocarditis coupled with heart failure and a potential neoplasm on the tricuspid valve. Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 57-year-old Caucasian male patient who has a complex ocular history. The patient previously underwent cataract surgery in his left eye (OS) in 1984. In 2000, he presented with recurrent orbital cellulitis and endophthalmitis in OS, leading to blindness and significant pain. Consequently, an enucleation was performed.

Histopathology from the enucleation revealed a malignant uveal melanoma of the epithelioid cell type, which had invaded the sclera and orbital tissues. Notably, no signs of metastatic disease have been observed during the four-year follow-up period.

The patient requires further evaluation and follow-up to rule out any late-onset metastatic complications related to the malignant uveal melanoma. Given your expertise in oncology, I am referring the patient to you for continued monitoring and management.

Thank you for your attention and assistance in this matter.

Best Regards,
[Your Name]
[Your Contact Information]
referral_content: The patient requires further evaluation and follow-up to rule out any late-onset metastatic complications related to the malignant uveal melanoma. Given your expertise in oncology, I am referring the patient to you for continued monitoring and management.

I am writing to refer an 81-year-old female patient who recently underwent excision of a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) on her left ala nasi. Postoperatively, a 180-degree rotation island flap measuring 2 cm in width and 5 cm in length was used to reconstruct the defect using a perforator from the left nasolabial area (LNA), following successful excision of the cancer. The referral is specifically requested for a follow-up evaluation to ensure that the reconstructed site is healing well and to monitor for any potential complications. Sincerely,
Dr. John Doe

The injury required the transfer of an 18x7 cm ALT-FC flap to cover the defect, which extended to the subcutaneous and muscle layers. Dr. John Smith

I am writing to refer Mr. John Doe, a 73-year-old male with a significant cardiac history including a prior PTCA of the left anterior descending artery and ramus intermedius.

Mr. Doe recently underwent dipyridamole stress testing following a nondiagnostic exercise EKG which was terminated due to non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. During the dipyridamole stress test, apical hypokinesis was noted at baseline and remained unchanged. Ventricular tachycardia recurred during the test.

Given Mr. Doe's history of coronary artery disease and complications during the recent stress tests, I believe it is crucial for him to undergo further evaluation and management by a specialized cardiologist. The consideration should be given to optimal medical therapy and potential further intervention to manage his condition and prevent further cardiac events.

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter.

Best regards,
Dr. Jane Taylor
referral_content: Given Mr. Doe's history of coronary artery disease and complications during the recent stress tests, I believe it is crucial for him to undergo further evaluation and management by a specialized cardiologist. The consideration should be given to optimal medical therapy and potential further intervention to manage his condition and prevent further cardiac events.

Dear Colleague,

I am writing to refer a 13-year-old female patient with a history of being bedridden and requiring tube feeding for 18 months. Blood tests identified elevated antibody titres to Coxsackie virus, which persisted for a year. She underwent monthly intramuscular immunoglobulin injections and showed a gradual recovery over two years. Currently, in her 20s, she is fully recovered and employed full-time.

The reason for this referral is to evaluate any potential long-term sequelae related to her previous Coxsackie virus infection and prolonged immobilization. Your assessment and recommendations for any necessary follow-up or preventive measures would be highly valued.

Please feel free to contact me if you need any additional information.

Best regards,
Dr. John Doe
referral_content: The reason for this referral is to evaluate any potential long-term sequelae related to her previous Coxsackie virus infection and prolonged immobilization. Your assessment and recommendations for any necessary follow-up or preventive measures would be highly valued.
